details.title: Effect of CVD-SiO/sub 2/ film on reliability of GaAs MESFET with Ti/Pt/Au gate metal

p: Yoshihiro Saito was born in Fukui, Japan, in 1963. He received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in Industrial Chemistry from Tokyo University, Tokyo, Japan, in 1986 and 1988, respectively.
In 1988, he joined Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Yokohama Japan, where he has been engaged in the development of GaAs IC. He is now a Senior Engineer in Transmission Device R&D Lab.
Mr. Saito is a member of the Japan Society of Applied Physics.

authors.affiliation: Transmission Device R&D Lab, Sumitomo Electr. Ind. Ltd., Yokohama, Japan

p: Tatsuya Hashinaga was born in Tokyo, Japan, in 1963. He received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in Electronic Engineering from Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan, in 1986 and 1988, respectively.
In 1988, he joined Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Yokohama Japan, where he has been engaged in the development of GaAs IC. He is a Senior Engineer in Transmission Device R&D Lab.

p: Shigeru Nakajima was born in Osaka, Japan, in 1959. He received the B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from the Himeji Institute of Technology, Japan, in 1982 and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from Osaka University in 1984 and 1996, respectively.
In 1984, he joined Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., Japan, where he has been engaged in the development of GaAs IC. He is a Chief Research Associate of Transmission Device R&D Lab.
Dr. Nakajima is a member of the IEEE Microwave Theory and Techniques Society, the Japan Society of Applied Physics and the Institue of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineering of Japan.

authors.affiliation: Transmission Device R&D Lab, Sumitomo Electr. Ind. Ltd., Yokohama, Japan
authors.name: S. Nakajima

details.abstract: The effect of CVD-SiO/sub 2/ films on the reliability of GaAs MESFET with Ti/Pt/Au gate metal was investigated. It was found that the mean time to failure (MTTF) of MESFET with 350/spl deg/C-depositied SiO/sub 2/ was only about one-seventh of that of the ones with 440/spl deg/C-SiO/sub 2/. It was also found that, in the storage test at 300/spl deg/C for 24 hours, diffusion of Pt into GaAs was accelerated when the SiO/sub 2/ deposition temperature was lower than 380/spl deg/C. FT-IR spectra indicated that the lower deposition temperature leads to a higher concentration of the residual hydrogen in SiO/sub 2/. Thermal differential spectrometry (TDS) demonstrated that hydrogen in SiO/sub 2/ could migrate even below 300/spl deg/C. In conclusion, the residual hydrogen in SiO/sub 2/ causes the degradation phenomena.

links.abstract: Catastrophic source-drain burnout is an important failure mode in GaAs power FET's. In this paper we show that short-term (instantaneous) and long-term (aging) failures have different physical origins provided the underlying drain ohmic-contact weakness has been suppressed by use of a recessed n<sup>+</sup>drain ledge geometry. With this drain configuration, instantaneous burnout is due to thermal runaway of the buffer/substrate when local temperatures reach the 500-550°C range. For our typ...

context.text: It has been reported that the surface oxide, whose composition is \${\hbox {As}}_{2}{\hbox {O}}_{3}\$, causes burn-out failure to GaAs MESFET [1].

links.abstract: Investigations into unexplained RF gain changes versus time during life tests have lead to the conclusion that hydrogen gas in quantities as small as 0.5% of ambient atmosphere can cause significant performance degradation in as little as 168 h at elevated temperatures (125 degrees C). This amount of hydrogen has been readily observed in Kovar hermetic packages with 0.1 cm/sup 3/ internal volume. The apparent mechanism for this degradation is the conversion of gaseous hydrogen into atomic hydrog...

context.text: Regarding the effect of hydrogen on the MESFET reliability, Camp and others [3] reported the conversion of gaseous hydrogen into atomic hydrogen in the Pt layer, and the subsequent doping compensation by the atomic hydrogen, which diffused into the channel.

references.title: Hydrogen effects on reliability of GaAs MMICs
references.text: W. O. Camp et al., "Hydrogen effects on reliability of GaAs MMICs", GaAs IC Symp. Technical Digest, pp. 203-206, 1989.
